results.title: Nashville [DVD]
results.brief_description: During a weekend in Nashville the Grand Ole Opry celebration of country music is running parallel with a presidential election campaign. The film is meant to be a mosaic of contemporary American life. It moves from a barrage of simultaneous moments in the lives of more than 20 different characters to the presentation of multiple perspectives in a single unifying event. Although containing 27 songs and 13 on-stage performances, the film’s explicit cultural indictment runs very much against the grain of the American musical. Multi-track sound-recording, multiple cameras and low-light sensitive film stock all facilitated the impressionistic, spontaneous feel of the film. Cast includes: Karen Black, Ronee Blakely, David Arkin, Ned Beatty, Keith Carradine, Geraldine Chaplin, Lily Tomlin, Gwen Welles.

results.title: NASA: the big missions
results.brief_description: NASA: the big missions is an amazing collection of newsreels and NASA film footage of the American exploration into space spanning from 1959 through to 1979. It includes previously unseen Movietone reports and official NASA Aeronautics and Space Reports capturing some of the most dramatic and momentous occasions in space history. The video opens with newsreel footage (1959-1961) of animals in space, the first step towards man’s flight into space, then follows chronologically from the Project Mercury missions (1961-1963), the Project Gemini missions (1965-1966) and eventually the Project Apollo missions (1966-1975), including footage from two of the most famous missions, Apollo 11 when Armstrong and Aldrin became the first men to walk on the moon (20 July 1969), and the Apollo-Soyuz mission (15 July 1975) where the American astronauts and the Russian cosmonauts transfer to each other’s space ships in a rendezvous in space whilst orbiting around earth. Also includes footage on Space Lab and the development of the Space Shuttle (1975-1979). This video provides a wonderful insight into the operations of NASA, the rigorous training of the American astronauts (the first seven being Donald Slayton, Alan Shepard, Walter Schirra, Virgil Grissom, John Glenn, Leroy Cooper and Malcolm Scott Carpenter), the designing and trialling of the various rockets and space ships, the many failed launches as well as the successful and newsbreaking missions, and the continuing development and commitment to achieve what at times seemed to be unachievable - man’s conquest of space and the desire to explore the unknown. Contains some breathtaking photography shot live from space and rare archival footage of significant historical value.

results.title: NASA 3: the American space odyssey
results.creator_credit: Robert Drew, Audio Productions, United States. National Aeronautics Space Administration, Drew Associates and John Nicholas
results.brief_description: Part three of a three part series of programs about NASA space flights entitled “The American Space Odyssey”. “Skylab: 4 rooms, earth view”: the establishment of the space station Skylab, launched on May 14, 1973, marked a transition within NASA from space exploration to space exploitation. Presented by E.G. Marshall, this documentary looks at the purpose of Skylab as an economic venture and the experiences of the three crew who lived on the station. “Who’s out there?”: presented by Orson Welles and narrated by Peter Thomas, this program speculates on the eternal question “is there extraterrestrial life?”. Taking the famous radio broadcast of H.G. Wells “War of the worlds” as a starting point, the film explores our fears of invasion by unfriendly aliens. A symposium of experts debate the question and Welles offers some philosophical ramblings.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Drew, Audio Productions, United States. National Aeronautics Space Administration, Drew Associates and John Nicholas

results.title: NASA 2: the American space odyssey
results.creator_credit: AV Corporation, United States. National Aeronautics Space Administration, Lynne Lucius Moore and Don Wiseman
results.brief_description: Part two of a three part series of programs about NASA space flights entitled “The American Space Odyssey”. “Gemini project” is an award winning documentary produced by NASA, introduced by astronaut Charles Duke and narrated by astronaut Bob Marcato, that details the space missions that preceded and laid the groundwork for the Apollo Project. The Gemini project consisted of ten missions carried out in the space of eighteen months and provided data and test results essential to the success of the Apollo missions. “Apollo 16: nothing so hidden” introduced by astronaut Charles Duke and narrated by astronaut Stan Wessel, details the mission to the lunar highlands of the moon which cover 80% of its surface. Astronauts Charlie Duke and John Young scaled mountains in their lunar vehicle to collect samples and conduct experiments. This mission is also memorable for the impressive photos of the earth and space taken with a special camera. “Astro smiles: laughs in space”, introduced by astronaut Wally Schirra takes a look at some of the more light-hearted moments of astronauts experiences in space.

results.title: NASA 1: an American space odyssey
results.creator_credit: Don Wiseman, AV Corporation, United States. National Aeronautics Space Administration, Graphic Films and Lester Novros
results.brief_description: Part one of a three part series of programs about NASA space flights entitled “The American Space Odyssey”. “NASA 1” traces the history of American space travel championed by United States President John F. Kennedy and contains extensive footage from various space missions including Apollo 7, Apollo 9 and Apollo 13. This documentary comprises archival images of various take-offs, the earth from outer space, the launching of satellites, the effects of zero gravity, astronauts amending equipment whilst hanging in space, and craft re-entry to earth. Astronaut Walter Cunningham describes the events that surrounded the dramatic mission that was Apollo 13’s, whilst other astronauts describe the process of launching a rocket, the emotions, the perils and the joys of space flight, narrating their experiences whilst watching videos of their trips. Also features excerpts from an earlier documentary by Lester Novros (who worked on Kubrick’s “2001: A Space odyssey”), with images of galactic whirlpools, stars, the universe and black holes taken from satellites, both manned and unmanned as well as theories of universal evolution and the wonders of space. Narrated by William Shatner (“Star Trek”).

results.title: Narritjin Maymuru (A)
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, Philip Robertson and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Narritjin Maymuru is a respected aboriginal artist. This series of films profiles the man and his work, as well as looking at the traditional way of life he and his family follow at Djarrakpi near Yirrkala in the Northern Territory. Photography is by Dean Semler.

results.title: Narritjin in Canberra
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Narritjin Maymuru (A)”.
The film shows Narritjin and Banapana and their families at work in their ANU studio and later an exhibition of their work. In 1978 Narritjin Maymuru and his son Banapana were awarded fellowships as Visiting Artists to the Faculty of Arts at the Australian National University in Canberra. This program shows Narritjin and Banapana and their families at work in their A.N.U. studio. With anthropologist Howard Morphy, Narritjin conducts a seminar session for anthropology students. He explains his technique of bark painting and discusses some of the meanings behind the paintings. At the end of their stay in Canberra, Narritjin and Banapana hold an exhibition of their Manggalili art.

results.title: Narritjin at Djarrakpi. Part 2 (A)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Narritjin Maymuru (A)”.
This program continues the life of Narritjin and his family at his clan settlement at Djarrakpi. Throughout Narritjin tells of his feelings about Djarrakpi and of his hopes for the future. A continuation of the study of the life of Narritjin and his family at his clan settlement at Djarrakpi, where they live largely off the land and the sea, producing bark paintings and craftwork to sell at Yirrkala. Gives an insight into Narritjin’s family life and his role as an educator to his sons.

results.title: Narritjin at Djarrakpi. Part 1 (A)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Narritjin Maymuru (A)”.
Narritjin Maymuru and his family are establishing a small settlement at Djarrakpi, an important Manggalili clan site on the northern head of Blue Mud Bay in the Northern Territory. Narritjin is a renowned artist and he and his family produce bark paintings and craft work to sell at Yirrkala. This program, together with Part 2 [507335], gives an insight into Narritjin’s family life and, through his paintings, his role as an educator, teaching his sons about their clan land and its ancestral history.

results.title: Nargun
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Nargun and the stars”.
Based on Patricia Wrightson’s novel of the same name, this is the story of Simon Brent, a city boy who comes to live with his country relatives after the death of his parents. In this episode Simon must finally face the menacing giant rock, The Nargun.
